Legal_Issue: Is the trademark GRILL GEAR & Design registrable under section 12(1)(b) of the Trade-marks Act?
Procedural_Stage: Appeal under section 56 of the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: Registrar initially found the mark descriptive; new evidence showed no widespread use of 'grill gear' in trade and design element added distinctiveness
Decision_Outcome: Trademark is registrable as not clearly descriptive and has distinctive elements
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show trademark is registrable despite initial refusal
Credibility_Factor: New evidence presented on common usage and distinctiveness
Legal_Rule: A trademark is not registrable if it is clearly descriptive or deceptively misdescriptive of the goods or services
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from Registrar's refusal to register
Grounds_for_Claim: Trademark application rejected due to alleged descriptiveness
Key_Evidence_Considered: Usage of term 'grill gear' in trade, presence of design element adding distinctiveness
Court_Result: Allowed the appeal, set aside Registrar's decision, approved application
Defendant_Response: Registrar opposed registration on grounds of descriptiveness
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence on trade usage, trademark design
Remedy_Sought: Set aside Registrar's decision and approve registration
Legal_Provision: Section 12(1)(b), Section 56 of the Trade-marks Act
Authority: Registrar of Trademarks, Court on appeal
